productions.title: Bobo the Cheerleader's Song
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTIST: Little Peetie Love
productions.body: I wrote the song and recorded it under the stage name of Little Peetie Love, don’t ask me why. Jack Holzman actually considered releasing it but look at the letter of rejection he sent me.

productions.title: Sound of Summer Showers
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTIST: Jerry Yester
productions.body: Jerry Yester did a great job on a song I wrote. We recorded several other songs together. I think Henry Diltz and some other pals sang backup.

productions.title: A Little Lovin'
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTIST: Dwain Story
productions.body: My old partner Dwain Story sang on a song I wrote called "A Little Lovin". I'm pretty sure some guys from The Spoonful backed him up on this one.

productions.title: The Slurp
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTISTS: Dee & Zee
productions.creditsText2: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTIST: Dwain Story
productions.body:
After I resigned from the banjo business I stayed in Greenwich village, trying to write songs and make some recordings, including the pathetically naive concept of starting my own dance craze, which I called The Slurp.

I recorded several different songs and artists, including my old partner Dwain Story, as well as Dee & Z, Denny Doherty and Zal Yanovsky. Understandably none ever got released. A totally cringe worthy concept from the start.

tracks.title: The Slurp - I Got the Word
The Slurp - Slurpin to the East and West

productions.title: Rooty Toot
productions.body: The first of John’s songs we recorded together was called Rooty Toot, a song he had written as a teenager with his cousin. The two of us went into the studio. John played guitar, harp, and sang lead vocal. We had some vocal backup singers and we put on chimes and clapped.
productions.body2: This was the demo version we recorded of John’s first composition, written shortly before we got the spoonful going.
productions.creditsText: WRITER: John Sebastian // ARTIST: John Sebastian

productions.title: Cass, Denny Doherty, Jerry Yester, Zal
productions.creditsText: ARTISTS: Cass Elliot, Denny Doherty, Jerry Yester, Zal Yanovsky
productions.body: I recorded several tunes with this cast of characters, Cass, Denny Doherty, Jerry Yester, Zal and possibly others.

productions.title: Lady Godiva
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTISTS: John Sebastian, Jerry Yester
productions.body: Erik goes surfin! Arrangement help from Felix Pappalardi, with John Sebastian and Jerry Yester singing lead. Henry Diltz and others in the backup vocal group.

productions.creditsText: WRITERS: Erik Jacobsen & Henry Diltz // ARTIST: A Surfin' Crew

productions.title: The Strangers
productions.body: Talented group of guys from New York City with a sweet and singular take on Motown and R&B classics as well as some great original songs.

tracks.title: I Need Your Love Inside Me

productions.title: The Sellouts
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Erik Jacobsen // ARTIST: The Sellouts
productions.body: The group, from Long Island, was the first rock band to show up in The Village, Joe Butler sang lead. I signed them and we cut these 3 sides. Before we could get going, I was distracted trying to get a rhythm section together for the Spoonful. The Sellout’s guitar player, Skip Boone, suggested his younger brother Steve for bass. Shortly thereafter, the Sellouts drummer, Joe Butler took over as the Spoonful’s drummer.

productions.title: Ken & Bobby Fischler
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Ken Fischler // ARTISTS: Ken & Bobby Fischler
productions.body: A one shot attempt on a nice song that didn’t make.

productions.title: Ray Roe
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Ray Roe // ARTIST: Ray Roe
productions.body: I liked the songs but really couldn’t find anybody to play them for.

tracks.title: Dyin' a Dime at a Time

productions.title: Ken Melville
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Ken Melville // ARTIST: Ken Melville
productions.body: A sad tale of an aspiring musician who tried too hard to escape his frustration and pain.

productions.title: Tim Hardin
productions.creditsText: WRITER: Tim Hardin // ARTIST: Tim Hardin
productions.body: I made this demo with Timmy, in Gold Star Studios in 1966, I think. The drummer sounded like the guy we worked up "If I Were a Carpenter" with.  It's raggedy and loose-for interest value only.

tracks.title: See Where You Are and Get Out
He Could be a Hollywood Star
It's Hard to Believe in Love for Long

productions.title: Plum Creek Boys - at Oberlin College
productions.body: Someone sent me this tape of my Bluegrass group at college recorded a year or two before I went professional. I don’t know who all was playing or singing. We never knew who would show up to play at any given performance. Sloppy as could be, but we were going for it! You gotta start somewhere.
